rush.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to move very quickly, especially because you need to be somewhere very soon
rush.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: A small girl rushed past her.
Mo rushed off down the corridor.
rush.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to do or decide something too quickly, especially so that you do not have time to do it carefully or well
rush.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He does not intend to rush his decision.
When we first met, neither of us wanted to rush things.
I’m not rushing into marriage again.
rush.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to take or send someone or something somewhere very quickly, especially because of an unexpected problem
rush.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Dan was rushed to hospital with serious head injuries.
The Red Cross rushed medical supplies to the war zone.
rush.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to try to make someone do something more quickly than they want to
rush.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I’m sorry to rush you, but we need a decision by Friday.
They felt they were being rushed into choosing a new leader.
rush.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if water or another liquid rushes somewhere, it moves quickly
rush.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to attack a person or place suddenly and in a group
rush.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: They rushed the guard and stole his keys.
rush.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to give parties for students, have meetings etc, in order to decide whether to let them join your fraternity or sorority (=type of club)
rush.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to go through the process of trying to be accepted into one of these clubs
rush.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: rush
to move very quickly, especially because you need to be somewhere soon
He was rushing out of his office in order to go to a meeting.
There’s no need to rush - we have plenty of time.
hurry
to do something or go somewhere more quickly than usual, especially because there is not much time
People hurried into stores to escape the rain.
You ll have to hurry or we 'll be late for breakfast
I hurried through the rest of my workout and showered as quickly as I could.
race
to go somewhere as fast as you can
She raced downstairs to tell her mother.
He raced back to his car and called for help.
tear
to run very quickly and without really looking where you are going, because you are in a hurry
I saw two boys tearing across the field towards the tree.
He tore down the stairs and out of the house.
They tore out of the building.
dash
to run somewhere very fast, especially only a short distance
Bob dashed across the road to his friend’s house.
Her heart was pumping furiously as she dashed through the kitchen to the front door.
I dashed outside to try to rescue the unfortunate creature.
hustle
to hurry when you are doing something or going somewhere
You better hustle or you’re going to miss the school bus.
hasten
to hurry somewhere, especially because you need to do something
Suddenly frightened, she hastened back to where her friends were standing.
She took a deep breath and then hastened after him.
rush.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a sudden fast movement of things or people
rush.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: At five past twelve there was a mad rush to the dinner hall.
She felt a cold rush of air as she wound down her window.
Her words came out in a rush.
rush.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a situation in which you need to hurry
rush.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I knew there would be a last-minute rush to meet the deadline.
Don’t worry, there’s no rush. We don’t have to be at the station until 10.
I had to do my homework in a rush because I was late.
I’m sorry, I can’t talk now – I’m in a rush.
rush.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a situation in which a lot of people suddenly try to do or get something
rush.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: There’s always a rush on swimsuits in the hot weather.
the rush to put computers in all schools
rush.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a sudden strong, usually pleasant feeling that you get from taking a drug or from doing something exciting
rush.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: The feeling of power gave me such a rush.
rush.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a sudden very strong feeling of anger etc
rush.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: I felt a rush of excitement when she arrived.
A rush of jealousy swept through her.
rush.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: a type of tall grass that grows in water, often used for making baskets
rush.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: the time when students in American universities who want to join a fraternity or sorority (=type of club) go to a lot of parties in order to try to be accepted
rush.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to move or go somewhere very quickly and in large amounts
rush.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Foreign capital is rushing into Asia at an incredible rate.
rush.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to do something too quickly, especially so that you do not have time to do it carefully or well
rush.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: There’s plenty of time — we don’t need to rush.
The company chose not to rush development of the new engine.
rush.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to do something eagerly and without delay
rush.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Investors are rushing to buy bonds.
rush.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to take or send something somewhere very quickly, especially because of an unexpected problem
rush.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: We had to rush the backup disk to the office.
Volkswagen rushed in its bid early.
rush.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: to try to make someone do something more quickly than they want to
rush.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: I’m sorry to rush you, but we need a decision by Friday.
Don’t let them rush you into signing the contract.
rush.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a situation in which you need to hurry
rush.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: We don’t see any rush or urgency to buy right now.
They are in no rush to make a deal.
rush.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: when a lot of people suddenly try to do or get something
rush.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: We’re going to see a big rush for Western goods.
a rush on swimsuits in the hot weather
The rush to buy shares did not last long.
rush.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: the time in the day, month, year etc when a place or group of people are particularly busy
rush.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: The cafe is quiet until the lunchtime rush.
